title: Is this a valid proof that 0 is not equal to 1? - Quora

response.answer_text:
No. If you don’t know that [math]0 
eq 1[/math], then you don’t “know enough” about numbers to talk about multiplication. When you’re doing foundational-level proofs like this, you have to state what your axioms are. Using something like [math]a = b[/math] implies [math]ac = bc[/math] is only valid if it’s either one of your axioms or it’s a theorem derived from your axioms. Elementary proofs about numbers usually start with Peano’s axioms.[1] In your case, the number 1 is defined to be [math]S(0)[/math] (where the successor function, [math]S[/math], and the natural number [math]0[/math] are defined in the axioms). The eighth axiom states that for every natural number [math]n[/math], [math]S(n)
eq 0[/math], from which you can immediately conclude that [math]S(0)
eq 0[/math]. The claim the [math]0
eq 1[/math] is so foundational that any proof is either going to be using axioms that make it almost trivial (as with Peano’s axioms), or else you’ll have to spell out what it is you mean by zero and one—you’d need what’s called a “model” of your numbers. Footnotes[1] Peano axioms - Wikipedia

Hm… I would say it is a bit weird. I think it’s just as obvious that 0 doesn't equal 1 as it is that not all numbers are equal. In informal mathematics, 0 =/= 1 is an obvious statement that doesn't require proof. In (more) formal mathematic, you have to deduce that 0 =/= 1 from the axioms that define the real numbers, or make it an axiom itself. My favorite system has an axiom that for all real numbers x, exactly one of the following is true: x is positive, -x is positive, x = 0. It also states that the positive numbers is a NON-EMPTY subset of real numbers closed under addition and multiplication. So if 0 = 1, then (as you proved) all real numbers equal 0, so there are no positive real numbers. So if you can prove that not all numbers are equal, then it's a valid proof.
